    SUBJECT:   Food stamp answer

    TO: Elena Kagan ( CN=Elena Kagan/OU=OPD/O=EOP @ EOP [ OPD ] )
    READ: UNKNOWN

    TEXT:
    Here is the food stamp answer, still writing up other one. sorry for
    delay. let me know if you want it another way (disk).

    ==================== ATTACHMENT   1 ====================

    6E73807468617480776580646F6EF01C04F074806E65656480746FCF6368616E67658074686580

You had asked about an item in a recent Cabinet weekly report that described USDA's approval
of a Hawaii request to waive the food stamp work requirement. The report noted that USDA has
approved waivers in 14 states to date. You asked whether this means that we don't need to
change the law in this area since single individuals in waiver states can go on getting food
stamps.

Waivers are granted only to areas with unemployment rates over 10% or with "insufficient jobs",
usually as defined by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Although these waivers do offer significant
relieffrom the law, they would help only about 30% of this population even if states take full
advantage of the waiver option. None of the waivers granted to date are state-wide. For
example, West Virginia's request for a state-wide waiver was turned down. Rhode Island was
able to exempt 90% of its food stamp popUlation. Illinois's waiver only exempts portions of the
city of Chicago.
